commentBody:
My favorite encore clues from last week:

[Spot likely to smear]  (6)(2)
[Solos at a party, say]  (4)


ATTACK AD
CUPS

Well, I've tried posting my Five Favorite Original Clues list twice now, but it's been emued, apparently.  They will probably both show up in the fullness of time (and I apologize in advance for the dupe!).  Could have been the word THONG that did it, an answer last week, who knows?

When I got to the NE, I noticed that the French condiment was going to be SEL, but I was working the across clues, so I figured I'd just hold the L in my mind for when I got to the answer that crossed.  When I got there, I saw that I'd have gotten MILLIE Bobby Brown without any crosses, so retention of the L in my mind turned out to be unnecessary.

I felt the same about the theme.  The answers filled in so fast that I got all those long ones easily without even understanding what they had to do with 40A, the clue of which I stopped reading after "Finger or toe"...that's a dictionary definition of DIGIT.  

Eventually, someone will tell me they used the revealer to figure out JACKSON HOLE or CHERRY PIT, but that was not my experience tonight.

Random notes:  The OPERA clue was a riot.  Reminded me of Andrzej's opinion of musical theater.

SLY NOD struck me as sort of "green paint" (for those not familiar, this means a multi-word answer that isn't a set expression in the language; "green energy" is, because there's no pink, purple or orange energy, but "green paint" isn't.)

YOYO--[Toy on a string that's not a kite]?  Isn't "Toy on a string" enough?  It's almost like "Feline pet that's not a lynx" in my mind.

On the other hand, I got 64D on crosses.  Would I have known it?  No WEI.
Iranians and Iraqis will be shocked by 29 down. As an Arab, I am. They would also be shocked to be grouped together.
Got a little slowed down by close but wrong fills (Arabian and Come Out Well) but it was fun and the theme was cute!

My five favorite original clues from last week
(in order of appearance):

1. Minimal coverage provider?  (5)
2. Like some car exteriors and hairy legs (5)
3. They'll make it up to you  (5)
4. It's often rapped but never spoken  (5)
5. Deposit that might gather interest?  (3)


THONG
WAXED
LIARS
GAVEL
ORE

Sam,
CTO is usually Chief Technology Officer (not Technical).

Caused a flashback (not at all drug related, just a normal memory)‚Ä¶ ‚ÄúYou dig?  Cool, I dig.  Far out.‚Äù

Wearing bell bottoms and a head band.  Like we all did.
Starting the week with Robert Benchley means it's going to be a good week. üíÉüèª
Feels a lot more smoother when typing on mobile; still got issues with letters disappearing tho
this is the first crossword that i completed without needing any clues or looking anything upü•π and in half the time as usual. progress!!ü§ùüèæ

I am a good and proper Minnesotan now.

WORKED OUT WELL did not occur to me, never wood have withut crosses.

Instead, I had WORKEDOUTokay.

"Pretty good" instead of  "well", or "excellent" every time.

And we never, never, never take the last slice of pizza or the last piece of candy.
The puzzle was great! Not an issue at all! Laughed at 24A when I figured it out! Keep it up, guys! ;)
Cute Monday. Had to cheat and look up ORO to get MOJO. For some reason just could not see APART, though was pretty sure of JACKSON HOLE just based on letter probabilities.
2:30 under my Monday average. Nice puzzle. Got slightly hung up on Roi and wei. My brain wanted rei for both. Fun puzzle

After attending the jazz opera Madam Bootyfly in Soho, where he had seen Millie Fitzgerald scat her way through the closing number, James Bond put his Astin Martin in gear with a growl and flew in a streak to the casino for a showdown with the agent from LYCRA with the missing digit. 

Inside, a woman dressed only in a piece of cake, with oil paint mascara, gave him a sly nod and passed him a martini. "Shaken, not stirred," she purred. Bond crossed to the baccarat table. Across from him sat Monsieur Sel from LYCRA, lacking a forefinger, and on either side were two tough looking Asians who introduced themselves to Bond as Mr. Aloo and Mr. Ali. There was a fifth man at the table, the mysterious Ursa Oro: a notorious gangster they called the Golden Bear. 

"Well, gentlemen," Bond smiled, laying a single Euro on the table, "I can tell this is going to cost me...where's the nearest ATM?"

The game commenced and Bond began losing. "What can I offer, in lieu of money?" he asked. "What's the rarest thing I have?" He stretched his open palm toward them. In it lay what looked like a dried out cherry pit. There was a lull in conversation throughout the whole room. Monsieur Sel tapped his cigar's ashes into a cup. "Your offeur iz taken." 

But the martini was spiked with LSD! A huge hamster lacking a digit sat across from him. "Aces" it squeaked. "Roi," announced Bond sadly, as Mr. Aloo, now a large sow, glared at him. "This won't work out well," Bond thought. "I've lost my mojos."
Tied my All Time Speediest Monday

"I thought you wanted to search for fossils here!"
"No. We'd be making a dig mistake."

(But I went there once, looking for a dino. It was a site for 'saur eyes.)

Pretty normal Monday, I didn't get the theme until reading this because I thought when they meant "If read as two words" they meant the four other answers.

Took me a little longer than average for a Monday just because two specific squares in the cross of NEILL/MILLIE/SEL.  Actor names and foreign language words not from Spanish or Japanese are often weaknesses of mine.

(Thankfully by now ESAU is getting used so often I think of it immediately for any four letter Bible name.)

Monday NYT Crosswords are hit or miss. Some are amazing, some are just okay. And this one, in my opinion, is both. The theme for this one was relatively unique, and it‚Äôs also kind of fun to have the grid design allow for across and down theme entries.

Good clues - Messages on which you might be cc‚Äôd; Gesture suggesting ‚ÄúI see what you did there‚Äù; Half of a train track.

But then there‚Äôs the ‚Äúmiss‚Äù section. All relatively minor  perspectives I‚Äôve taken against this puzzle on the whole.

For one thing, SOHO is a relatively difficult answer for a Monday, but could easily be gotten from context without LYCRA directly on top. Filling in that part of the puzzle was the hardest section. Not that it was too bad, but for a Monday, it felt unbalanced. Also, ASTIN intersecting with NEILL was a bit challenging, considering I wasn‚Äôt sure on either of the references.

Overall, more good than bad. A nice collaboration by the constructors. That‚Äôs my two cents.
ASHES and OAKS are right next to each other, and not cross-referenced. I love a good cross-reference. I don‚Äôt know‚Äî that‚Äôs just my two cents.

Run out of clothes? STREAK

I like this clue on a Monday because it's very gettable, and yet misdirection is involved. IMO this is how Mondays should introduce newcomers to how NYT crossword puzzle clues may work. Nicely done.

I'm admittedly not "Mr. Pop Culture", but the three intersecting proper nouns (14A, 15D, 30A) seemed a little obscure for a Monday.  And the cluing to 29D (clue:  "Iraqis and Iranians", answer: "Asians") seemed a little weird and unsatisfying.

Other than that, a fairly run-of-the-mill Monday.

Nice debut/collab for Dan. STREAK was brilliant. I liked the play on DIGIT/DIG IT. Numbers also come to mind for DIGITs. While I was waiting for my plane home today, I was scrolling Instagram and I saw several reels asking ‚Äúwhat‚Äôs Jenny‚Äôs number?‚Äù or ‚Äúwhat are Jenny‚Äôs DIGITs?‚Äù As each person was asked the question, it displayed the year they were born. I sang the answer in my head immediately ü§£ Of the ones I watched, the vast majority born in the 60s to 70s got it right away. A few born in the 80s got it, two from the 90s and one from the 00s. All three of my kids would know the answer!! https://youtu.be/6WTdTwcmxyo?si=SIEbKAiJxnCUq1EZ
esau and scat somewhat incendiarily?/inauspiciously? crossed, it might be said.

Any puzzle with Sam NEILL in it is okay by me. And it's fitting to find him in a puzzle featuring various types of DIGs. 
Always a pleasure, CC (Zhouqin) and Dan.
Fun theme, but crossing actor last names  (14A/15D) is always a natick for me, and a HOHUM natick at that.

No dugout ü§î

A good Monday afternoon puzzle. The actor crosses maybe could have been avoided but they caused little trouble. 

Thanks
This was a great one for the ‚Äúonly use the Across clues‚Äù challenge. I managed it in 13:00. No Downs! Great crossword!

second monday crossword solved! 
loved the asians clue. its easy to forget that the middle east is asia, even though i live there.
66 across was a little frustrating bc it couldve been either lyres or lutes, with only 2 letters different. it messed me up for a short while
Enjoyed this one. Took a hot second to process the theme. ü§¶üèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Thanks, Dan & Zhouqin! Y‚Äôall have a wonderful Monday!

Lovely past clues listed by Sam for STREAK.  Another I've seen is [Take off and run].  One that I've haven't seen but might work on a Saturday:

[Go without?]

I'm part of a mountain biking chat group: MAMIL, middle aged men in 32A. 
I'm a bit past the MA part of the acronym, but you're as young as you feel!

Enjoyed the puzzle! Keep cranking 'em out!

I nearly finished without look-ups but was scuppered by names I had never heard of - ASTIN, NEILL and also CTO.

And 22A - I know a PISTON is part of a motor but what is a "hipster"?

Otherwise, I enjoyed this and I like the theme.

This puzzle was not a one-trick pony.






(Sly nod?)

Maybe digging is in our genes, like it‚Äôs in dogs‚Äô genes.  I remember that when I was a kid, the first thing I‚Äôd do after getting to the beach is dig the deepest hole I could.  

I did some more digging post-puzzle to determine the origin of ‚ÄúHole‚Äù in ‚ÄúJackson Hole‚Äù.  Turns out the area named after fur trapper David Jackson, who worked the area in the 1820s, and ‚ÄúHole‚Äù was a trapper‚Äôs term for a large mountain valley. Huh!

I did notice that the theme nouns ‚Äì HOLE, DITCH, PIT, and WELL ‚Äì can also be verbs.  Then I saw words that can be both nouns and verbs all over the grid.  A partial list: STREAK, SCAT, SCAN, RAIL, SLAM, TANK, GROWL, YOYO.  

A little more digging revealed that 30-50% of high-frequency vocabulary in English can be both noun and verb, but only about 10% of all the words in the dictionary can.  You‚Äôre welcome.

I love the constructor mind that saw the two interpretations of DIGIT and had to make a puzzle out of that.  We all owe much pleasure to Constructor Mind.

A memory, a TIL, a language quirk, and a brush with cleverness ‚Äì all in the box today, turning my neutral brain alive.  Thank you, Dan and Zhouqin, and congratulations Dan on your NYT debut!

Nice Monday workout. Just a bit on the slow side for me, but things fell together pretty smoothly. And... didn't catch on to the them until I was almost done. That's always a nice touch. Puzzle finds today were inspired by ESAU. Here's one - a Sunday from June 12, 1994 by the great Frances Hansen with the title: "About Miss Daw." Four 21 letter grid-spanning theme answers in that one, each just clued as "Start of a verse", "More of a verse," etc. Here those are: MARGERYMETALEPRECHAUN WHOSAIDHISNAMEWASESAU ALOTOFHERAPLOMBISGONE SINCESHESAWESAUSEESAW Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=6/12/1994&g=106&d=A I'll put the other puzzle in a reply. ....
Gif? It‚Äôs two; two; two pronunciations in one; not unlike agile. üòÄ
Found the theme a bit HOHUM, but liked the unusual arrangement of the thematic entries and the revealer. Seemed like a perfectly fine Monday puzzle to me.
Iraq and Iran are in Asia?  Huh?

There were a few misdirects, and I just want Dan (congrats, I take it you're new) to know that I fell for each of them!  2D Not together:  ALONE, of course!  26A Like an envelope that's ready to be sent:  STAMPEdang! And so on and so forth.
It did add some nice spice to the puzzle, Mondays being....well, Monday-easy.

Now, about 56A:  Is a NOD a "gesture"?  NODs are overt; how does one manage a SLY NOD without arousing suspicion?  (I really need to know this....because I've been using a WINK, myself.)  I mean, you have to sneak it out if you want to be SLY.  Things like NODding and raising one's cup are kind of obvious, wouldn't you say?  
Please sneak your answer in below.

On second thought and after examining a map, I reluctantly conclude that these countries fit into ‚ÄúAsian‚Äù better than any other designation. Istanbul is famously the city where you can walk across a bridge from Europe to Asia and scarcely break a sweat. 

HOWEVER, thats where clarity ends. If we agree to fold in ‚Äúthe Middle East‚Äù to Asia, we have a unit that stretches from the Bosphorus Bridge across the Himalayas from Pakistan to India, and onward to Ho Chi Minh City?  Singapore?  Jakarta? Manila?
And north through China, Japan, Korea and only ending at the Bering Strait?  Do Russians agree that they are Asian?  If you go East from Europe, are you of necessity in Asia?  Or is there a carve out for Russia?  Ukraine, Belarus and the Baltics are European and Russia is Asian? 

It‚Äôs all very confusing to one whose geographic knowledge mostly comes from concert tours, and reading about wars and famines, but it made for a fun hour with my maps this morning!

And, I‚Äôd rather hear answers from other puzzlers than Wiki or Google!
Fun one!
Congratulations on the debut! I'm not sure I've run 10 miles over the course of my entire life.

A fun Monday, to be sure. Took me a minute to understand the theme, and then a good chortle.

Congratulations on the puzzle, and having CC as your co-constructor! Why not start with the best!
As a member of my high school archaeology club, I hole-ly endorse this puzzle's theme. Can you DIG IT? I knew that you could.

I was surprised to learn that MOJOS are tangible things.¬† And magic, no less.¬† I thought...well actually my ideas about MOJOS were very vague and half-formed.¬† To me, a MOJO was like an aura: When you have your MOJO, people really notice, admire and respect you.¬† When you lose your MOJO, you are but a pathetic shell of your former self.¬† Since I first heard the word no more than 10 years ago, perhaps I can be forgiven for my fuzzy comprehension.

Re the wonderful Robert Benchley quote on OPERA  -- Benchley having been a founding¬†member of the Algonquin Round Table and a great wit -- reminds me of an incident¬†from my own life.¬† I'm at a book publishing party in the 1970s.¬† I'm standing in a group of people, none of whom I know.¬† One man -- in his 70s or perhaps even early 80s -- is mesmerizing the group.¬† He is droll and witty, a spellbinding raconteur with marvelous stories to tell.¬† Afterwards I ask someone at the party I do know "who that man wearing the [whatever] and standing over there near the [whatever] is?

"Oh that's Marc Connelly" I'm told.¬† The name means absolutely nothing to me. though it probably should have.

I look him up the next day.¬†  I discover that he's not only a well-known playwright, but a distinguished member of the Algonquin Round Table.¬† Does he have sparkling wit?¬† Is he a great storyteller?¬† Is rain wet?¬† More than half a century later, Connolly remains the most charismatic and irresistible raconteur I have ever met in¬†real¬†life.

Thanks for a terrific start to the solving week, Dan and Zhouqin! I loved the theme and DUG your mix of clever clues!

Happy Monday, everyone!

One more puzzle find - or actually... 3 puzzles with the same theme. First a Sunday from April 3, 1994 by Ernie Furtado. Answers in that one: 

AGENTAGENT
EAGLEEAGLE
INDEMNITYINDEMNITY
VISIONVISION
DECKERDECKER
OCCUPANCYOCCUPANCY
SPEAKSPEAK

And... a Thursday from February 18, 1999 by Robert H. Wolfe. Theme answers in that one: 

CROSSCROSS
AGENTAGENT
TAKESTAKES
DATESDATES
EAGLEEAGLE
PUMPSPUMPS

And... a Tuesday from December 4, 2001 by Michael Shteyman. Answers in that one: 

AGENTAGENT
DIGITDIGIT
HELIXHELIX
DUTCHDUTCH
TIMETIME
DATEDATE
TAKETAKE
REEDREED

That's it. 

....

@Andrzej

Your facts are correct, but your tone is not what I usually encounter in these forums; most interactions here are enjoyable/humorous and leave both parties laughing. 
Yours, sadly, projects a condescension that casts a pall over the happy interest either which I posed this question. 

This also goes for other responses of yours which I see in this column. I‚Äôm certainly not the comment police, but belittling your fellow puzzlers see seems to run counter to the basic aim of games: to have fun.

I can dig it, he can dig it, she can dig it, 
We can dig it, they can dig it, you can dig it
Oh, let's dig it. Can you dig it, baby?

Today‚Äôs fun theme made me think of ‚ÄúGrazing in the Grass‚Äù by The Friends of Distinction, a group founded by none other than Jim Brown, the football player. 

Adding to the discussion about Sean Astin, in his youth his mother (Patty Duke) told him that Desi Arnaz Jr. (son of Lucille Ball) was his father. She had been having an affair with then 17-year old Desi Jr. (much to the dismay of Lucy) and two other men at the time of Sean‚Äôs conception. As an adult he learned the identity of his biological father through DNA testing. Patty Duke‚Äôs life story is fascinating and sad in many ways.

Well, this puzzle certainly brought me back to the 70s.
Funday Monday! Grazie!

Fun,  fast, and amusing puzzle and it looks like we have a terrific new constructor in our midst. This was a respite from the tough (for me) offering yesterday, which I finally finished late last night before falling asleep. 
I got some chuckles from today‚Äôs theme, and my first chuckle came from the Robert Benchley quote about OPERA üòÇ
Thanks to the whole team for giving me something to chuckle about. Life is very busy these days and worries abound. I need all the opportunities for joy I can get.
Went from AryANS to ArIANS to "of course lol"

Oh my goodness, for some reason I put Texas into 13A immediately. Like, first thing that popped into my head was Texas! What!? I did think of it as a compliment about the toughness and resilience of Texans. Still, weird!  I already had MADAM, but I thought it might be some kind of mountain at 1D. üòÜ

Fun puzzle! Loved the clue for STREAK at 24A. Classic! 

I DIGIT!

(Of course, they're all dead, and almost forgotten)

The table talk in Washington
I hear by special messenger,
Is brightened by the presence there
Of Kiplinger and Kissinger.

The anecdotes are wittier,
The chitterchat flows ripplinger,
As of the moment on the bus
When Kissinger met Kiplinger.

"My name is Mr. Kiplinger,"
Said Kiplinger to Kissinger.
"And I'm Professor Kissinger,"
Replied his fellow passenger.

"You'll kindly note my g is hard,"
Said Kiplinger to Kissinger;
"Some people call me Kiplinjer,
And nothing is depressinjer."

"Hard g to me," said Kissinger,
"Is sentimental goo.
Kissing-er means more osculant.
More osculant than who?"

"One dowager," said Kiplinger,
"She goes beyond Kiplinjery.
She dragged me to the opera
To add Yseult* to injury."

Kiplinger grew progressively pressinger;
"Do you know my good friend Arthur Schlesinger?"
Kissinger answered his fellow passenger,
"No, but I know an Arthur Schlesinger.
In a city named for George or Martha,
How odd that we each should know an Arthur!
Let's have a foursome at Burning Tree,
Your Arthur and you against mine and me."

--Ogden Nash

*you know, the one where Tristan gets stabbed in the back, and goes on to sing an entire third act?

I've always wonder how much LYCRA actually helps a biker.  Has anyone done a study comparing the difference in speed or efficiency with and without the LYCRA.

I think that without the LYCRA, the biker would really be STREAKing!!!
Oh, Kammaaaannn.

Okay - late puzzle find, absolutely the strangest I've ever encountered. A Sunday from April 25, 2010 by Elizabeth C. Gorski with the title: "Monumental achievement." Can't imagine having any kind of a chance at filling this one in. Six across answers for which the clue is just: [ ] And some of the answer to those clues: CHEERLEADINGFORMATION IMAGEONADOLLARBILL YOGAPOSE THELOUVRE CARDGAME THREEDIMENSIONALSHAPE But one of them actually had a clue after the [ ]. That was: "[ ]: that was the creation of an architect born 4/26/1917. And that answer was: GLASSDESIGNBYIMPEI And... then there was a shape implied connecting several highlighted squares with the letters: P Y R A M I D Here's the link to that puzzle if you want to go take a look: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=4/25/2010&g=66&d=A Might re-post this tomorrow. ...
Nope, it wasn't THONG, as it worked in the above post!

Lewis,
Looks like it was a random glitch, not a ratite grab. It showed up.

@Lewis

It was probably THONG and WAXED right next to each other : )

@Lewis

Guess you were assuming it was the same old thong and dance.

@dutchiris

üòÜ  You never run out of material, do you?

@Francis

Material?  It's the way my head works.  Puns pop in. What can I do? They're part of the pleasure of language.

@Francis

There's a joke somewhere in there about a thong's lack of material, but I'm not cheeky enough to make it.

@Kara

You'll get to the bottom of it.

Steve,
(1) Since I like to savor the puzzles while solving, I read the second half of the revealer clue (after entering DIGIT from reading the first half), and [CHERRY]PIT and  [WORKOUT]WELL went in faster as a result. 
(2) SLY NOD *is* an expression (you apparently have not heard or read).
(3) Re: YOYO. It's Monday; kite is also four letters.
(4) I'll bet CC didn't have to Google 64D.
(5) Please pass the salt.

@Barry Ancona

Agree with you on SLY NOD it‚Äôs a thing just like a knowing glance

@Barry Ancona

1. Different strokes.  I like to savor the puzzles when I'm done.
2. I was indicating how the phrase struck me...just my personal experience. And when I Googled "sly nod" (in quotes), I found most, if not all, of the top hits were metaphorical, as in "that scene was a sly nod to the film..."  No actual head movement involved.  Sure, the AI answer went literal, but AI can't even represent English words in a drawing.
3. My point was that even on Monday, "toy on a string" makes me think of YOYO and not kite.
4. I didn't say CC did; I might have had to.
5. Avec plaisir.

@Nellie

What continent do you think Iran and Iraq are on?

@Steve L
‚ÄúWe have always been at war with Eurasia.‚Äù

@Nellie

Amazing the things that shock people, and the things that don‚Äôt.

@Nick

Au contraire. Oceania is at war with Eastasia. Oceana has always been at war with Eastasia.

@Steve L

The Other America? Soon enough a certain Iunatic may rename it, threatening tariffs if the idea is not accepted.

@Caitie

That's a common error - Iranians may be Muslims, and Arabs may have been the ones to initiate the spread of Islam, but Iranians are mostly Persians, not Arabs.

@Andrzej
This I knew from linguistics. Farsi is on a separate branch of the Proto-Indo-European tree, unconnected to Arabic except for some loan words.

@Lewis
I loved your Item 2. Of course, in another era it wouldn't have passed the breakfast test. üòè
To wit: https://www.nytco.com/person/jason-sobel/
I feel like I suddenly fell into a bizarro world, here.

Mr Dave,
You didn't read your own "cite" well enough. After the unsupported nonsense in the overview, every one of the specific articles uses only Technology. And, of course, I didn't say there was anything wrong with the column.

@Molly in Wake Forest
Where does Benchley appear? I've gone through clues and solves and can't find any trace.

@SBK

Look at the clue for 13A. It‚Äôs a quote from him.
@SBK when I see @Solverado, I think of Chevy Silverado. I like what you see much better!! Good tune

@SBK/@Jacqui J 
I think of the 1980s western Silverado directed by Lawrence Kasdan starring, among many, many others, Kevin Kline, Linda Hunt and Brian Dennehy.

@Yer

That happens to me if I ask Siri a question in the middle of a crossword solve. I just have to exit out of it and resume it to fix.
@mariel :) That's great! Always feels good when that happens! Keep up the great work!

@mariel :)

That first clean win is a really nice moment.

@mariel :)

And many more!
Wohoo!! Well done.

@Francis
LOL -- But do you take the first one?

@SBK

My understanding of the protocol for the first piece is that it's ok to take it *if* it's offered to you.  

It's also ok to take the first piece if you offer it to someone else, and they decline.  Obviously, if they accept, you're free to go ahead with the second piece.

I believe I'm paraphrasing the Minnesota Constitution properly, but I'm not a lawyer, so please don't take this is legal advice.

@Francis
My Granny's rule was: presented with a mixed selection of cakes, some with cream or chocolate, some very plain -  even if the biggest and best cake was right there in front of you, you reached over and picked up the plainest one. It was like a 'good manners' test.
@Jane Wheelaghan interesting! I was taught to take the piece closest to you, no matter what.

@Francis

We never take the last piece of anything!!

@Francis

Dose Minnesota have a Museum of Last Pieces?  It would have to be pretty cool.

@dutchiris

DOES (sigh)

@dutchiris

üòÜ  Great idea!  I think we should start one if there isn't one already.

@Megan

Yeah‚Äî that tripped me up too; I‚Äôve never seen ROI in the Times, just REI and REY
@Steve L But ROI is usually clued as Return on Investment if my recent memory serves me well. How many times has it appeared as this meaning?

Carl,
Your memory is not serving you well. ROI has been clued as a profitability metric just once in dozens and dozens of times in the past 25 years.

@Carl

What Barry said.

@Joe P

Congrats. Is That Going To Be the Title of Your Autobiography?

@SP

Or Amy Santiago's se√ó tape?

@SP

"From Blaze to Blur -- How One Man's Speediest Monday Became Just Another Monday"

@Andrzej

Replies the nthis thread have also been gutted by the "moderation". This is way beyond unprofessional.

@Mike

Ice age, make no bones about it, it's always best to wear a mastadon some gloves. You don't know where those creatures have been.

Mike,

Click here for a great shale on really old puns:







;)

@Mike

Jur a sick punster, you know that?

@Mike
I've gone on many such Trex myself.

@Chris
I must have gotten SEL on the crosses alone. I didn't even realize it was there until I read your note. But 'gettable via crosses' is the whole trick of this game.

@Chris

Better add ENOS, son of SETH,  to that list.

@Peter

ESAU is the OREO of the Old Testament.

@Bruce

Don't you just *love* how *unique* each and every puzzle is at the NYT? I literally can't express it myself.
@Bruce maybe it means 'uniquier than most'

@Dvd
As in less equal?

@Peter
How are they related?
Unless you're thinking of a country singer duo....


Ducking and running...

@Mean Old Lady

Both are trees.

In country music, the OAKS generally means the Oak Ridge Boys, who are a quartet.  

There are no ASHES, unless you're talking about Ashley McBryde or Ashley Monroe or Ashley Cooke, who are all solo artists.  And Ashley Gorley is a songwriter.
Don't you hate it when I post something positive and there is nothing interesting you can say in a reply? ü§™
@Andrzej I agree and I loved STREAK as well

@Andrzej

@CCNY

Strange tie into mathematics.  

Often the solution to a difficult math or physics problem is to find an inventive way to break it down into two or more smaller, more manageable problems.  

This splitting of the problem often is done as am approximation, which makes the problem solvable, but only approximately.

That fits so well with your "connected minis".

@Mean Old Lady

I don't do those, either.

@Francis
One of my favourite tricks! It's why I still see circles as a bunch of polygons smoothing out as the number of sides converge on infinity.
My other favourite was to assume the opposite of the proposition and prove it false. Of course, that only works for binary problems.
Ahhh, maths! üòå

@Jane Wheelaghan

Sean ASTIN is the son of 60s TV star Patty Duke and the adopted son of her husband, 60s TV star John Astin.

Duke had a self-named sitcom in which she played dual roles as a down-to-earth teenager and her posh "identical cousin"; John Astin was Gomez in the original Addams Family series.  

I don't know whether you ever got either of those shows in the UK, but they were both quite popular here.  

Knowing all this makes it easy to remember Sean, even if you're unfamiliar with his work.

@Judith Nelson When I am in Israel, I am told it is Asia, but when I turn on the television, it says CNN Africa. (Or maybe it wasn't CNN, but that's not the point.) Looking at the map, it's the teeniest tiniest piece of whichever continent it is. The confusion is not just mine, that's for sure! https://www.worldatlas.com/articles/what-continent-is-israel-in.html

@Judith Nelson Here's what constitutes Asia: https://www.britannica.com/place/Asia The boundaries are arbitrary (some cultures consider all Eurasia one continent, which is scientifically more accurate). But generally they are topologically (rivers, mountains, lakes) rather than politically based (national borders). Thus, Russia, some of the Caucasus Mountain and other former Soviet countries, Turkey, and Egypt are transcontinental nations. Iraq and Iran, however, are clearly wholly in Asia. Some MENA (Middle Eastern/North Africa) designees are Asian, some are African. The US Census Bureau muddles things by making some categories continent-based, and some ethnically-based. A friend of mine with Israeli citizenship, who identifies as Jewish and white, almost put "Asian American" on her daughter's financial aid application because technically, it was true. But we don't usually think of Israelis that way, and neither does the Census Bureau, apparently.

@Andrzej Most of us definitely are. No doubt about it. But look at the size of our country and compare that to Europe or even Asia. Hopefully (!) the average American knows our own geography as well as the average European knows European geography.

There's a play called "Lonely Planet" that I got to be in once.

There was a long, fourth wall breaking discussion of the Mercator projection, the problems it solved and the problems it created.

I really loved giving that monologue.  And yes, the Mercator projection is the source of much good and much ill.

I think the thing that clarified it for me was the statement, obvious when pointed out, that it is impossible to place a three dimensional map of the globe on a two dimensional surface without distortions of some kind.

@Francis
I like the modified Mercator map that has a sort of tulip-petal effect at the top and bottom, to minimize the distortions which increase as you move away from the equator. You have these empty gashes along the edges but the land masses are better proportioned.

@Judith Nelson

My parents insisted I start learning as a kid in the gray and gloomy Poland of the 1980s, when the only language the state cared about teaching us was Russian (which I don't speak). They bought a VCR (an almost unheard of extravagance; we were all poor then, as a matter of course, and electronics were imported from the West in small numbers) just so I could watch shows in English, on pirated tapes smuggled from the West. Then came 1989, democracy, market economy, and with it satellite TV and some time later the internet. I consumed pop culture in English, and read books in the language, too. Over time I became proficient enough to publish scholarly papers in English. And here I am now. It was a lifetime effort, basically.

@NYC Traveler

Sure, I'll pitch in, although you are right that SP already covered it quite well.  And I agree with SP in full.

It would be a mistake to pick any one post by Andrzej and to draw conclusions about him.  Any single post (and that applies to a lot of people here) is likely to give  a distorted picture.

The totality of Andrzej's posts here demonstrate a quick wit and a depth of thought about a number of topics, as well as a quite clarity of understanding of himself, his likes and dislikes, that I wish I had.

I'm not criticizing Judith for her observation, but I would advise that there's more going on that can be discerned from any small subsets of his comments.

I think the same thing about my comments.  For example, I had a running joke about Heidi having a kangaroo.  One thing led to another, and suddenly I find I'm writing wild posts about trying to get a kangaroo of my own.  Anyone reading them would think I've entirely lost my mind.  And I haven't.  Not entirely.

Long story short, having been interacting with Andrzej in this weird and wonderful community for quite some time, and I would be surprised in the extreme to find that any of his playfulness harbored even the slightest ill will towards anyone here.

Ok, I'm going to consider this a golden opportunity to repeat a joke I wrote earlier, but it was late in the comment cycle, and I don't think anyone read it.

A Texan was ashamed that he came from the second largest state in the union.  So he went to Alaska, walked into a bar as asked what he needed to do to become an honorary Alaskan.

The old-timers saw this as an excellent opportunity to have some fun with this guy.  So they told him, "Sure.  You first of all need to strip down to your underwear and climb Mt. Eagle just outside of town here.  Then you need to find a grizzly bear and wrestle him.  After that, you have to find a woman and have relations with her.

So the Texan headed out into the blizzard in his underwear.

Several hours later, he reappeared at the bar, and was a bloody mess.  Huge claw marks, bite marks, just a disaster.

And he says "Ok, where's this woman I'm supposed to rassle?"

@Andrzej

That reminds me of one of the most beautifully constructed jokes I've ever heard.

Sorry to say there was a time when it was common  in the US to make fun of the Poles for not being very bright.  (The US has now proven beyond a shadow that we're not ones to talk.)

So this was during the Soviet era, a train was chugging through Poland.  On the train, and seated facing each other were these people:  A Polish patriot, a beautiful Polish woman, a little old Polish woman, and a high Russian official.

The train goes into a tunnel, and in the darkness, there is the sound of a kiss, followed by a slap.

When the train emerges, the Russian official has a developing black eye.

The old Polish woman is thinking "What a brave young woman to strike that officer despite his official standing."

The beautiful Polish woman was thinking "Why did that Russian kiss that old lady instead of me?"

The Russian is thinking, "That pretty Polish woman struck me, rather than the Pole who actually kissed her, but she's so beautiful I'm not going to take any action."

And the Polish patriot is thinking "What a brilliant Pole I am to kiss the back of my hand, strike a Russian official, and nobody says a word."
